From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Galician

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Latin attrahere.

Verb

[edit]

atraer (first-person singular present atraio, first-person singular preterite atraín, past participle atraído)

  1. to attract

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of atraer (irregular)

First-person
(eu) 		Second-person
(ti) 		Third-person
(el / ela / Vde.) 		First-person
(nós) 		Second-person

Related terms

[edit]
  • atracción
  • atractivo
  • atraente

Further reading

[edit]
  • “atraer”, in Dicionario da Real Academia Galega (in Galician), A Coruña: Royal Galician Academy, 2012–2025

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Latin attrahere (“to draw, pull”). Cognate with English attract.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /atɾaˈeɾ/ [a.t̪ɾaˈeɾ]
  • Rhymes: -eɾ
  • Syllabification: a‧tra‧er

Verb

[edit]

atraer (first-person singular present atraigo, first-person singular preterite atraje, past participle atraído)

  1. to attract, to lure

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of atraer (irregular) (See Appendix:Spanish verbs)

gerund atrayendo

1Mostly obsolete, now mainly used in legal language.
2Argentine and Uruguayan voseo prefers the tú form for the present subjunctive.
